editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

II. The Miracles of Art, de≈øcribing the mo≈øt Magnificent Buildings, and other Curious Inventions in all Ages, as Solomons Temple, The Seven Wonders of the World, and many more Excellent Structures and Rarities throughout the whole Earth.

div.head: To the READER.
div.p:
THere is no Per≈øon of any Age or ∆≤nder≈øtanding, but mu≈øt needs acknowledge that the la≈øt Forty Years has been as it were an Age of Prodigies and Wonders in the≈øe three Kingdoms, ≈øo that it may be no former time can parallel ≈øo many ≈øtrange Tran≈øactations as have happened in ≈øo little ≈øpace, and therefore as an Ingenious Per≈øon ≈øays
A Book of Prodigies is fit
In times Prodigious to be writ.

div.head: The Surprizing Miracles of Nature in the Heavens, Earth, and Waters.
div.p:
STrange and Wonderful have been the Miraculous Productions of Nature in all Ages, or rather of the God of Nature, and Divine Providence: St. Auflin, that Famous and Reverend Father of the Church, defineth Miracles to be tho≈øe things which happen beyond the Expectation, or thought of the Beholder, and begets in him a Miraculous Contemplation, yea, oftentimes horrour and amazement; whereof there are two kinds, True and Fal≈øe; the fal≈øe Miracles are ≈øuch as are not really as they ≈øeem to be, but meerly acted by the Power of Nature, although ob≈øcure and hid; The True are performed by the Power of God, above and beyond all the Faculties of created Nature, partly to procure Admiration, and partly to confirm the Faith of Men; ≈øuch were the bringing back of the ≈øhadow Ten Degrees in the Dial of Ahaz, for Hezekiah; A Virgin to conceive with Child, and yet remain a Virgin: To draw water out of a hard Rock: To cau≈øe the Sea to divide a≈øunder; The Sun to ≈øtand ≈øtill: To cau≈øe Manna to fall from Heaven: To turn Water into Wine; and many of the like kind recorded in
the Holy Scriptures; And the≈øe were formerly u≈øed for the Confirming of the Faith both of Jews and Chri≈øtians; but are not now nece≈ø≈øary, ≈øince the Writings of the Prophets, Evangeli≈øts and Apo≈øtles are ≈øo generally preached unto all.

Yet hath not the Almighty left him≈øelf without Witne≈øs, nor mankind without warnings of approaching Judgments, and De≈øolations, by Prodigious Signs, and Wonderful Appearances in all times of the World; thereby if po≈ø≈øible, to deter them from their Evil Practices, and to induce them to repentance and Reformation; of which the very Heathens were ≈øen≈øible, for we may find in the Roman Hi≈øtories, that there never happened any Remarkable Prodigy, but the People of every Sex, Age, and Quality, flockt, and ran to their Temples and Altars, making Prayers, and offering Sacrifices to their Gods for appea≈øing, and pacifying their incen≈øed Wrath; which may condemn the neglect and Contempt that is in tho≈øe who pretend to own the true Chri≈øtian Religion, and may teach us to repair to the true God, and implore his mercy and forbearance of pouring his Wrath upon us; In order whereunto it cannot ≈øurely be un≈øea≈øonable, nor unprofitable to Collect out of very approved Authors, the mo≈øt Remarkable Prodigies or Miracles that have appeared cither in the Heavens, Earth, or Waters, for ≈øome Thou≈øands of years in this Kingdom, and many other parts of the World; with the Tremendous Con≈øequences that have ≈øucceeded divers of them, as to Wars, Fires, Famines, and other dreadful Calamities in ≈øeveral Nations; upon ≈øome of which the Famous Dubartas thus Ingeniou≈øly Comments. page 14.

q.l: Here in the night appears a flaming Spire,
There a fierce Dragon folded all in Fire;
Here a bright Comet, there a fiery Stream;
Here Flying Lances, there a burning Beam:
Here ≈øeems a Horned Goat inviron'd round
With fiery flakes, about the Air to bound;
There with long bloody Hair, a Blazing-Star
Threatens the World with Famine, Plague and War.
To Princes Death; to Kingdoms many Cro≈ø≈øes,
To all E≈øtates, Inevitable Lo≈ø≈øes:
To Herd≈ømen Rot; To Ploughmen haple≈øs ≈øea≈øons;
To Saylers ≈øtorms; To Cities, Civil Trea≈øons.

div.p: I ≈øhall therefore proceed to give an Account of the mo≈øt Famous, and ≈øurprizing Signs and Wonders which I find recorded in Hi≈øtory.

I. In the time of the Carthaginian War, a River in Italy was ob≈øerved for near the ≈øpace of a day, to run perfect Blood; no accident that might cau≈øe it being perceived by any. In Hetruria the Heavens were ≈øeen to burn; In the City of Arimini 3 Moons were ≈øeen in one night by the Inhabitants; all the≈øe Prodigies appeared about the end of the fir≈øt Carthaginian War; In the ≈øecond War, after Hanno was overcome by Scipio, a Child of a Month old was heard to cry in the Street, Triumphi, Triumphi: In the Fields, near Rome, Ships were di≈øcerned in the Sky, and Men in long White Garments were perceived to march towards each other, but never to meet: It likewi≈øe rained Stones, and the Sun and Moon were ≈øeen as it were to ju≈øtle each other; and in the day, two Moons appeared in the Heavens; At Phala≈øcis the Heavens ≈øeemed to be rent in ≈øunder, and at Capua the Moon ≈øeemed to burn, and to bend down towards the Earth; A Green Palm-Tree in Naples took Fire, and burned away to A≈øhes; At Mantua a little Rivulet was turned into blood, and at Rome it rained blood: An Ox was likewi≈øe heard to ≈øpeak the≈øe Words, Cave tibi Roma; Rome look to thy ≈øelf. Soon after, ≈øeveral large, tall Ships appeared upon the River of Taracina in Spain; The Sun at divers times appeared of a bloody colour, many Temples and Hou≈øes in Rome were beaten down with Thunderbolts from Heaven, ≈øome of the Cities
En≈øigns, or Field-Colours were ob≈øerved to ≈øweat Blood; Two Suns appeared in the Heavens, at one time; It likewi≈øe rained Milk and Stones: A Comet in the form of a burning Torch was di≈øcerned to reach from the Ea≈øt to the We≈øt. In the Vileterman Fields the Earth rent a≈øunder in ≈øuch huge and frightful breaches, that Trees, and whole Hou≈øes were ≈øwallowed up in it, and it rained blood for two whole days together, about which time Hannibal received that notable overthrow by Scipio, which was the de≈øtruction of the famous City of Carthage, and the Conque≈øt of that Countrey to the Romans. Tit. Liv. Hi≈øt.

II. In the year of the World 3417, when Cyrus overcame Crae≈øus, King of the Lydians in Battel, a Child of ≈øix Months old is ≈øaid to have di≈øtinctly foretold in a Prodigious and wonderful manner, That his Kingdom ≈øhould be lo≈øt. A Dog and a Serpent ≈øpake very plainly and articulately to King Tarquinius, of which Sir G. Wharton writes thus.

In the year of the World 3842, at Veios in Italy, it rained Oyl extreamly, and Wool was al≈øo rained out of the Clouds; In the year that the Great Mithridates K. of Pontus was born, there appeared a huge Comet, which at fir≈øt ≈øeemed but ≈ømall, but afterwards ≈øpread it ≈øelf ≈øo much that it came as far as the Equinoctial Line, ≈øo that its extent equalized that Region of the Heavens, which we call the Milky Way; Another Come ‚Ä¢ likewi≈øe appeared in the fir≈øt year of his Reign, which ≈øhined ≈øo bright night and day for 70 days together, that the whole Heavens ≈øeemed all to be on a lig ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t Fire; for the Tayl of it covered the fourth part of the Heavens, and exceeded the Sun in brightne≈øs, and al≈øo its ri≈øing and ≈øetting took up the ≈øpace of four hours. Ju≈øt before the taking of Ari≈øtonicus, a dangerous Enemy to the Romans, news was brought
to Rome that the Image of Apollo at Cuma had wept for 4 days together; The South≈øayers were ≈øo a≈øtoni≈øhed at the Prodigy, that they had thrown the Image into the Sea, had not the old men at Cuma interceded for it; but the more expert A≈øtrologers ≈øaid, That thereby the De≈øtruction of Greece was foretold, from whence that Image was brought. Junius Syllanus going Procon≈øul into A≈øia, he with his Company ≈øaw a ≈øpark fall from a Star, which increa≈øed in Bulk as it came nearer the Earth, and being grown to the bigne≈øs of the Moon, it gave as much light as if it had been a cloudy day, and when it drew up towards Heaven again, it grew into the fa≈øhion of a Lamp; When Julius Cae≈øar had cro≈ø≈øed the River of Rubicon, contrary to the Decree of the Senate, the Heavens, as fore≈øeeing what mi≈øeries were to en≈øue thereupon, rained blood, and there happened a horrible Eclip≈øe of the Sun of 10 parts and an half, of which Lucan thus ≈øpeaks.

The ≈øame day that the Battle between Cae≈øar and Pompey was fought in the Phar≈øalian Fields, the Image of Victory which ≈øtood in the Temple of Minerva at Eulide, was ≈øeen to turn its face toward the Temple-door, whereas before it looked to the Altar; At Antioch in Syria, ≈øuch great noi≈øes, and Clamours were heard twice a day about the Walls of the Town, that the People affrighted with the ≈øuppo≈øed approach of the Enemy, ran out of the City in their Arms; In the Temples of Ptolemais, Organs, and other In≈øtruments were heard to play of them≈øelves, before Julius Cae≈øar was ≈ølain in the Senate Hou≈øe; and there being a Colony ≈øent to be planted in Capua, according to the Julian Law, and ≈øome Monuments being demoli≈øhed to lay Foundations for New Hou≈øes; In the Tomb of Capys, who was ≈øaid to be the Founder of Capua, there was

That when≈øoever the bones of Capys ≈øhould be uncovered one of the Julian Family ≈øhould be ≈ølain by the hands of his own Party, and that his blood ≈øhould be revenged to the great damage of all Italy; At the ≈øame time al≈øo tho≈øe Hor≈øes, which Cae≈øar had con≈øecrated to Mars, after his pa≈ø≈øage over Rubicon, did ab≈øtain from all kind of Food, and were ob≈øerved to have drops falling from their Eyes, after ≈øuch a manner, as if they had ≈øhed Tears. Al≈øo the Bird Regulus, having a little branch of Lawrel in her Mouth, flew with it into Pomp ‚Ä¢ ys Court, where ≈øhe was torn in pieces by divers other Birds that pur≈øued her, where al≈øo Cae≈øar him≈øelf was ≈øoon after ≈ølain with Twenty three wounds, by Brutus, Ca≈ø≈øius, and others. III. About the time that our Lord and Saviour was born, which was in the year of the World, 3849, and the 43 year of the Reign of Augu≈øtus Cae≈øar, many wonderful, and remarkable Prodigies ≈øhewed them≈øelves in the Heavens, and this more frequently than in former years, as Je≈øphas in his Jewi≈øh Antiquities te≈øtifies; which unu≈øual ≈øights occa≈øioned the M ‚Ä¢ gi, or Wi≈øe Men of tho≈øe times, in their Predictions to conclude, That „Äà‚óä„Äâ more than Ordinary Per≈øon would ari≈øe, or appear in the World: Which pre≈øages ≈øome Learned Per≈øons applyed to Augu≈øtus C ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øar, who then reigned pro≈øperou≈øly; But the more divinely in≈øpired, interpreted them to ≈øignifie him, who (as the Prophet I≈øaiah ≈øaith) ≈øhould have his Government upon his ≈øhoulders, Even the Saviour of the whole World; for be≈øides what the Evangeli≈øts mention, as of the Angel appearing to the Shepherds, and that Star which directed the wi≈øe men of the Ea≈øt to find out the place „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ .

q.l: As the Earth with a New Sun was ble≈øt,
So th' Heavens with a New Star is dre≈øt.

div.p:
It is likewi≈øe recorded by Paul Horatius, and Eutropius, Secretaries to Augu≈øtus, and likewi≈øe by Eu≈øebius, That at the time that Je≈øus Chri≈øt was born, it happened in Rome, that in a publick Inn was di≈øcovered, and broke forth a Fountain of pure Oil, which for the ≈øpace of a whole day continually i≈ø≈øued out in great abundance, and that at high Noon, in a clear and fair day, a Circle was ≈øeen about the Sun, as ≈øhining and re≈øplendent as the Sun it ≈øelf; About the ≈øame time, the Senate and People of Rome offered to Augu≈øtus the Title of Lord, which he refu≈øed, and would not accept of, unknowingly progno≈øticating that a greater Lord than he, was upon Earth, to whom that Title belonged; Come≈øtor in his Schola≈øtick Hi≈øtory affirms, That the ≈øame day of the Birth of Chri≈øt, the Temple in Rome dedicated by the Romans to the Godde≈øs Pax, fell to the Earth ruined; adding that when it was fir≈øt built by the Romans, they addre≈ø≈øed to the Oracle of Apollo, to know how long time it ≈øhould endure, who returned an≈øwer, Even until a Virgin ≈øhould bring forth a Child; which they judged impo≈ø≈øible, and that therefore their Temple ≈øhould la≈øt Eternally, neverthele≈øs at the Virgins bearing a Child, (even the King of Heaven) it fell to the Earth. Lucas de Tuy in his Chronicle of Spain writes, That he hath found in the Ancient Hi≈øtories of that Countrey, That by Computation of time; the ≈øame night wherein our Saviour was born, there appeared in Spain at mid-night a Cloud, which gave ≈øo great a Light, that it ≈øeemed like mid-day. I remember al≈øo (≈øaith my Author) I have read in St, Jerom, That when the Virgin fled with her Son into Egypt, all the Idols and Images of the Gods which were there, tumbled from their Altars to the Ground; And that the Oracles and An≈øwers which the≈øe Gods (or rather Devils) u≈øed to
give to ≈øuch que≈øtions as were propounded to them, then cea≈øed, and never an≈øwered afterwards: Rarities of the Creation. p. 84.

IV. About the fir≈øt year after the Birth of Chri≈øt, there were many Prodigious Births in Germany; Armies in the Air were ≈øeen at Rome; A terrible Eclip≈øe of the Sun, and dreadful ≈øtorms of Hail and Rain. V. In the Thirty Fourth year of our Ble≈ø≈øed Saviours Life, he was crucified by the wicked hands of the ‚Ä¢
Jews, which produced prodigious Effects, that
were afterward atte≈øted as well by Heathens, as Chri≈øtians; at the time of his Death a very great darkne≈øs happened in the day time, which continued from ≈øix a Clock, till nine; and yet there was no Eclip≈øe of the Sun, for it was at a full Moon, ≈øo that it was miraculous, and contrary to the Order of Nature, and only by the power of God, who deprived the Sun of its light for that ≈øpace of time; And therefore Dennis the Areopagite, being that day in Athens, and ≈øeeing the Sun ≈øo darkened, and al≈øo knowing as a man learned in A≈øtrology, and the cour≈øe of the H ‚Ä¢ avens, that ≈øuch an Eclip≈øe mu≈øt needs be contrary to the Rule of Nature, ≈øpake with a loud voice, ≈øaying, Either the World is at an end, or the God of Nature ≈øuffers: and upon this Account (≈øay ≈øome Authors) the Wi≈øe Men of Athens being a≈øtoni≈øhed at this Prodigy, they pre≈øently cau≈øed an Altar to be built to the ∆≤nknown God, after which St. Paul coming thither, reproved them for it, declaring to them, that Je≈øus Chri≈øt, the Redeemer of the World, who had ≈øuffered, was that Unknown God, whereby he Converted many of them to the Chri≈øtian Faith; which doth al≈øo demon≈øtrate that the darkne≈øs was over the whole Hemi≈øphere, ≈øince it was ≈øeen at Athens, and other places far remote from Jeru≈øalem; Yea the Moon being then at full, and having no light, but what ≈øhe hath from the ≈øplendour of the Sun, and being then in the Firmament that is under us, ≈øhe came to be violently eclip≈øed and darkned, ≈øo that the darkne≈øs was univer≈øal over all the World, becau≈øe the Moon and Stars can give no light, unle≈øs they receive it fir≈øt from the Sun.

It was likewi≈øe very ob≈øervable, and is acknowledged by the famous Hi≈øtorian Plutarch, though a Heathen, that after the Death of Chri≈øt, not only the Oracles of Egypt, but throughout the World cea≈øed, of which he can give no rea≈øon, (being ignorant of Chri≈øtianity) but that there were ≈øome Devils or Demons dead; However it was very remarkable, that Satan ≈øhould ≈øo

yet they overcame the≈øe difficulties, and their left Wing engaged with Walle≈øteins right; Then the Ring advancing with his right Wing, and ob≈øerving where the Croats or Crabats ≈øtood, and where the Cura≈ø≈øiers were who were covered with black Armour from head to foot, calling Colonel Stalban≈øh to him he ≈øaid, As for tho≈øe Fellowes the Crabats, I care not for them, „Äà‚óä„Äâ charge me tho≈øe black Fellows ≈øoundly, for they are the men that will undo us; The King fought at the head of his Squadron, him≈øelf being foremo≈øt with his Pi≈øtol in one hand, and his Sword in the other, and thus charging upon the Cura≈ø≈øiers, he was there overlaid with numbers, in≈øomuch that his men being in danger to be incompa≈ø≈øed, were forced to give ground, and retire towards their body; where the King received a ≈ønot in his Left Arm, which he not feeling at fir≈øt; would have led on ≈øtill, but ≈øoon after perceiving the blood to i≈ø≈øue out abundantly, and that part of his bone was broken, he called to Duke Albert of Saxon Lavoenburg, ≈øaying, Coren I am ≈øore wounded, help me to make my retreat; which whil≈øt the Duke and his A≈ø≈øi≈øtants were about to do, an Officer of the Cura≈ø≈øiers who too well knew the
King comes up, and ≈øaid. This is the right Bird, and ≈øo di≈øcharging his Pi≈øtol, ≈øhot him through the body, and him≈øelf was pre≈øently ≈øhot dead upon the place; The King was held up in his ≈øaddle, but pre≈øently fell; His hor≈øe al≈øo was ≈øhot, and ≈øo ran away without his Ma≈øter;

Ju≈øt at this time fell a great mi≈øt, the Sun which before ≈øhined very brightly, on a ≈øudden muffling up his face in a mourning Cloud, as if not able to look upon the fall of the King of Sweden; The Imperiali≈øts being now ma≈øters of the Kings Body fell to ≈øtripping it, one getting his ≈øpurs, another his ≈øword, another his Ring, and another his Buff-coat, &c. every one being greedy to get ≈øome part of his ≈øpoils; But before they could carry away his Body, the Swedes returned, and ≈øo charged their Enemies that they were forced to retreat, whereupon Stalhau≈øh recovering his Body, carryed it away in an Ammunition Waggon privately, ≈øo that few of his own Army knew of his death; All this while the four Swedi≈øh Brigades of Foot were hotly ingaged, and got ground of the Imperiali≈øts; The hor≈øe likewi≈øe after an hours fight drove them back, and got po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of ≈øeven Pieces of their Ordinance; but by this time the mi≈øt was ≈øo extreamly thickned by the ≈ømoak that the Swedes could not ≈øee to pur≈øue their advantage, yet it plea≈øed God to ≈øtrike part of the Imperial Army with a pannick fear, that above a thou≈øand German Hor≈øe ran all away together, one among≈øt them crying out; Oh I know the King of Sweden well enough, he is be≈øt at the latter end of the day; But the Chiefe≈øt fright was among≈øt the Ladies, and the Captains Wives, and other Women in the Reer of the Army, many of whom getting out of their Coaches, cut a≈øunder the harne≈øs, and mounted ≈øtradling upon the bare Hor≈øes backs, and ≈øo ≈øcudded away among the Souldiers; Several Women and Children were there trodden to death, nor did the Hor≈øemen ≈øtay till they had fled divers Miles; But in the heat of the Battle, Count Pappenheim
one of the Imperial Generals who was before ≈øent for, came in with his Hor≈øe and Dragoons, by who≈øe coming the charge was again renewed, but ju≈øt as he was ordering his Hor≈øe he was ≈øhot with a Falconet Bullet, whereof he pre≈øently dyed; His Officers flocking about him cryed out, O our General is ≈ølain, Our General is ≈ølain; and thereupon turning their Hor≈øeheads, they ran out of the battle without a ≈øtroke ≈øtriking; But the other Imperiali≈øts who were incouraged by his coming, maintained the fight with admirable re≈øolution, yet the charge was ≈øu≈øtained by the Swedes with much Gallantry for two full hours, wherein the greate≈øt lo≈øs fell upon two Brigades of old Swedi≈øh Souldiers whom the King did much rely upon, for the≈øe old Blades ≈øtood their Ground, till the Earth was covered with their bodies, yet they dyed not unrevenged, for they ≈ølew many of the Imperiali≈øts. and among≈øt them divers of great Quality.

Duke Bernard was very ≈øeverely be≈øet by the right Wing of the Imperiali≈øts that day, but no man ever behaved him≈øelf more gallantly than him≈øelf, charging his enemies no le≈øs than twelve ≈øeveral times; A little before Sun-≈øet the Mi≈øt cleared up, and then Duke Bernard took a ≈øurvey of his Army, which he could not do ≈øince he heard of the Kings death till now; He ≈øpake chearfully to the Officers and Souldiers, incouraging them to a new engagement, and though he found the mo≈øt part of his Army in great di≈øorder, yet with much pains he rallyed them for a new on≈øet, though not without much regret in the Souldiers one ≈øaying to another, alas Comerade, what mu≈øt we fall on again; The other replying, Come, if we mu≈øt, let us do it bravely, and make a day of it. The hearts of the Imperiali≈øts quaked for fear, ≈øeeing the Swedes advancing in ≈øuch good order again≈øt them; and thereupon their hor≈øe began to retreat, which the Swedes perceiving, they charged ≈øo home with their Great Guns, as put them into great confu≈øion; But then again ≈øo great a mi≈øt fell, that the Swedes could not
di≈øcern to pur≈øue their Enemies, ≈øo that the fight was only maintained about the Wind-mills, which continued with much briskne≈øs till ≈øix a Clock at night, when the Imperiali≈øts gave it quite over; This cruel and bloody Battle la≈øted above nine hours, and then Count Walle≈øtein marched away toward Leip≈øwick, leaving the Field and Victory to the Swedes, who lodged upon the ground all night, where they heard the lamentable groaning of the dying and wounded on both ≈øides, it being a fro≈øty cold night, wherein many a gallant man dyed of his wounds, who probably with ≈øea≈øonable help might have recovered.

The next morning the Swedes found the Imperiali≈øts had left all their Great Guns behind them, there were ≈ølain of the Swedes Three Thou≈øand, and of the Imperiali≈øts about Four Thou≈øand upon the place, be≈øides which the Boors killed near a Thou≈øand more of them who fled ≈øtragling away; The wounded were as many more as the ≈ølain, on the Swedes ≈øide were lo≈øt the King him≈øelf who≈øe death can never be ≈øufficiently lamented, his enemies them≈øelves giving him this Honourable Te≈øtimony, That he was the brave≈øt Enemy, and the be≈øt Captain that ever was in Chri≈øtendom, ≈øo that the Swedes and Prote≈øtants found them≈øelves to have gotten but a doleful, and a woful victory, lo≈øing that incomparable Conqueror, who was alone worth many hundreds of others; But he is dead, and was as heartily bewailed of the Germans as of his own Subjects, who yet profe≈ø≈øed, That their lo≈øs was un≈øpeakable, and in both their Chronicles ≈øhall his honourable memory be for ever famous, and his name ≈øhall live in their mouths in after Ages; Yet did not this glorious King dye, without ≈øome ≈øingular and miraculous Prodigies, which happened about that time in his own Kingdom of Sweden; Among≈øt others, at the very ≈øame hour and time when this battle of Lutzen was fought, there appeared ju≈øt over the Ca≈øtle, and Royal Palace at Stockholm a Virgin or Dam≈øel holding in one hand a burning Candle, and in the other a white handkerchief
which ≈øhe waved about; It was likewi≈øe noted and ob≈øerved, that all the doors in the Ca≈øtle though they were ≈øhut and lockt, yet they three ≈øeveral times opened of them≈øelves; At the ≈øame time a con≈øiderable River in Sweden was ≈øuddenly dryed up, ≈øo that for a whole day any one might go over it dry foot; Al≈øo in Smaland a Province of that Kingdom, the Bells without the help of any man began to ring, and ≈øound out, to the great a≈øtoni≈øhment of the Inhabitants.

Several other brave Swedi≈øh Commanders fell with their King, and many great men of the Imperiali≈øts; General Walle≈øtein at fir≈øt intended only to make a retreat to Leip≈øwick, but the Imperial Souldiers as ≈øoon as they heard the Drums beat a retreat, fell immediately to running, and the fright was ≈øo great that mo≈øt of them never came into order again, the Chief Officers confe≈øt, That if the Swedes had ≈øent but one Thou≈øand Hor≈øe after them, they might have cut off their whole Army. The King of Sweden was of a Maje≈øtick Countenance and a gallant Stature, above ≈øix foot high, of a ≈øtrong Judgment, natural vigilancy, and unweariedne≈øs; A ≈øudden danger ≈øeldom a≈øtoni≈øhed his Judgment, ≈øtill ≈øhewing mo≈øt vigor, where there was mo≈øt need of it; He was exceeding temperate in his Dyet, his feeding was upon ≈øtrong and ≈øouldierly Meats; But that which was mo≈øt commendable in him was his Religion, both Publick and Private; He was frequent in Prayers and Thank≈øgivings upon every emergent occa≈øion; He would pray a Shipboard, on Shoar, in the Field, in the mid≈øt of a Battle, as if Prayers alone were the ≈øure≈øt piece of his whole Armour; He was a ≈øtrict ob≈øerver of Martial Di≈øcipline, and a ≈øevere puni≈øher of Mi≈ødemeanours in his Camp; when he fir≈øt came into Germany, he ≈øaw that many women followed his Army; whereupon coming to a great River, his Men and Waggons being pa≈ø≈øed over, he cau≈øed the Bridge to be broken down, hoping thereby to be rid of his lumber, but they on a ≈øudden making a
terrible ≈øhreik, the Souldiers on the other ≈øide vowed not to ≈øtir a foot till the women were fetched over; whereupon the King finding that this ill humour was ≈øo generally di≈øper≈øed among≈øt his men, that it was dangerous to purge it all at once, ≈ømiled out his anger for the pre≈øent, permitting what he could not amend, yet this abu≈øe he afterward reformed by degrees: His Army won the day though they lo≈øt their King, which occa≈øioned one to compo≈øe this brief Elegy.

q.l: ∆≤pon this place the Great Gu≈øtavus dyed,
Whil≈øt victory lay bleeding by his ≈øide.

div.p:
A little before his death being in di≈øcour≈øe with his Chaplain Dr. Fabricius, he ≈øaid, That he thought God would ere long take him away, becau≈øe the People did ≈øo overvalue and deify him; At his fir≈øt coming into Germany having a de≈øign upon Stetin, and his Army being now upon the ≈øhore, and his Boats ready on the River to imbark them, but the Wind having been contrary for ≈øeveral days before, the King ob≈øerving it, kneeling down in the ≈øight of his Souldiers with his hands lifted up to Heaven, thus expre≈ø≈øed him≈øelf; O thou mo≈øt ju≈øt God, thou certainly knowe≈øt that I did not at fir≈øt undertake this Enterprize out of any ra≈øhne≈øs or ambition, but for the glory of thy mo≈øt Holy Name, and the defence of the Truth of thy Go≈øpel, here now therefore I call upon thee O God, and mo≈øt humbly be≈øeech thee, that with the Air of thy favour, and with a pro≈øperous wind, thou would≈øt be plea≈øed to breath upon this my undertaking for Chri≈øt his ≈øake, Amen; No ≈øooner were his Prayers ended, but through Divine Providence the Wind turned about with ≈øo full a Gale, that the whole Fleet pa≈ø≈øing up the River Oder, in two hours time ≈øailed up Twenty Miles, and unexpectedly came to an Anchor within a Mile of Stetin, whereby he wonderfully defeated the De≈øigns of the Imperiali≈øts, who intended within two dayes after to have laid ≈øiege to that City, had they not been thus miraculou≈øly prevented; When this
King came fir≈øt to the Crown, he re≈øolved to lay ≈øiege to Nottenburg Ca≈øtle, which the Mu≈øcovite had given his Father for ≈øome A≈ø≈øi≈øtance which he had afforded him; This Ca≈øtle ≈øtood in an I≈øland in the mouth of the mo≈øt raging and ≈øwift River of Nerva, his Commanders de≈øpairing of taking it, and being unwilling their young King ≈øhould receive a Repul≈øe in his fir≈øt attempts, they laboured to di≈ø≈øwade him from the action, yet he continued re≈øolute to pur≈øue it, and ≈øee how Almighty God wrought for him; The Be≈øieged Mu≈øcovites were ≈øtricken with ≈øuch Thru≈øhes, Warts and Bli≈øters in their Throats and Mouths, they could neither chew their Meat, nor ≈øwallow it down, whereupon they parlied and yielded up that impregnable Ca≈øtle to him, wherein he found a whole years provi≈øion of Victuals, be≈øides abundance of Ammunition.

Not long after this, he had a difference with the Dantzickers, and they had prepared twenty or thirty ≈øtout men of War, intending with the fir≈øt opening of the Spring, to have burnt up the Kings Navy in their Harbour; but toward the end of Winter, when this narrow Swedi≈øh Sea was frozen a yard or two deep, this young King cau≈øed his Boors to cut open the Ice for ten or twelve Miles together, which done, he came ≈øuddenly one night with his Fleet upon the Dantzickers, and burnt, ≈øunk, and took mo≈øt of their Fleet; Al≈øo in his Wars with the King of Poland, he conquered ≈øo many Towns from him in Pru≈ø≈øia and Livonia, that he inforced him by the mediation of King Charles of England, to make peace with him; In the≈øe wars with the Polanders his Army was never great, having for the mo≈øt part not above Five Thou≈øand Men, and yet with them he fought ≈øeveral Battles, beat and wearied out two Imperial Armies, took in the great and ≈øtrong City of Elbing with divers others and finally obtained his end upon his Enemies, though they were able at the ≈øame time to have come upon him with ≈øuch a number of Hor≈øe as had, according
to humane Rea≈øon, been ≈øufficient to have carryed him away, and five ≈øuch Armies as his was; He was ≈ølain in the Battel at Lutzen, Nov. 16. 1632. in the 38 year of his Age.

XLVIII. At Bu≈øhein a Village near Friburg in Germany, there happened this ≈øtrange Prodigy, there appeared in the Heavens a Twofold Rainbow, one white as Snow, and the other exceeding black, be≈øides another of a fiery colour: The next day from eleven, till two after Noon, another A≈øpect of a very white colour appeared: And about the time at Frane≈øtein hard by a Woman having bought ≈øome bread, and carrying it home, when ≈øhe came to cut it, blood i≈ø≈øued out from it; This Frane≈øtein is a pretty Town upon an Hill ≈øome ≈øixteen Engli≈øh miles from Dre≈øden, it was taken by the Imperiali≈øts in the year 1632 by Scalado, and meeting with ≈øome oppo≈øition, they in revenge cruelly put all, both Souldiers and Inhabitants to the ≈øword: And October 4. they a≈ø≈øaulted Friburg a hand≈øome Town upon the River Mulda ≈øome 10 Engli≈øh miles to the We≈øt of Frane≈øtein, and taking it by ≈øtorm, they likewi≈øe mi≈øerably de≈øtroyed the Inhabitants; near this place, Count Holcks men, (who was then Commander of tho≈øe Imperial Forces) taking di≈øplea≈øure again≈øt a Mini≈øter of excellent Learning in that Countrey, they fir≈øt hewed him all to pieces with their ≈øwords, and then flung his mangled Limbs to the Dogs to be eaten; But the Dogs, as if a≈øtoni≈øhed at ≈øuch ≈øavage cruelty, would not ≈øo much as touch his fle≈øh, or lick a drop of his blood; whereupon his Friends gathered up his pieces the next day, and buried them; and one of their own Authors relates, That the Crabats ≈øhewed them≈øelves ingenious to invent New Torments for the poor Prote≈øtants, and that it was frequent with them for want of Dogs meat to feed them with humane fle≈øh, which if ≈øo, we may truly ≈øay, Thatthough the Dogs were
the Man-eaters, yet certainly the Crabats were the Cannibals.

XLIX. In the month of Augu≈øt, 1632. at Kempten in Swabeland a ≈øtrange Mon≈øter was born of a Citizens Wife, the head was altogether fat, and without ears, the hands were ≈øtretcht out, and appeared all bloody between the fle≈øh and the skin, in the left hand there was a Rope, the Belly had two wounds as if prickt by a Sword, and the left knee ≈øeemed as if it had been twice broken, a cord being tyed about it: This goodly Town of Kempten was held by the Imperiali≈øts, and after many furious a≈ø≈øaults was taken by the Swedes in 1633. The Imperial Commander went to Reitaw, where he was beheaded, becau≈øe he had ≈øo ≈øoon ≈øurrendred the Place; Many other bloody skirmi≈øhes happened about this Town, and what mi≈øeries that, and the Countrey thereabout endured, when it was be≈øieged, and re-taken by the Imperiali≈øts can hardly be expre≈øt; It was brought to ≈øuch extremity of Famine, not much inferiour to tho≈øe dreadful ones of Samaria, and Jeru≈øalem recorded in Holy Scripture, or of Saguntum in Spain; Peru≈øium in Hetruria, or Tu≈øcany in Italy mentioned by other Authors; Many brave Citizens out of this and the Neighbour Towns were compelled by nece≈ø≈øity to bear Arms for a livelihood; Hor≈øe-fle≈øh was ≈øold at high rates, Dogs, Cats and Vermin were counted as good as Veni≈øon; For all Commerce and Trade being hindred, bread-corn was at an exce≈ø≈øive rate, and hardly to be purcha≈øed for money; In February, 1633. at Doben≈øhutz a Village in Althenburg, blood ≈øprang out of a Fi≈øh-pond, with ≈øuch a filthy ≈øavour, that if it were touched, they could not wa≈øh off the ≈øtink in 2 or 3 days; This Countrey was the ≈øame year lamentably ruined and plundred, and the bea≈øtly cruelty and licentiou≈øne≈øs of the Souldiers was exceeding mon≈øtrous: Many fine Towns and Villages were robbed and burnt to A≈øhes for defending them≈øelves, and the Inhabitants thereof, as well as of Doben≈øhutz mi≈øerably ≈ølaughtered: The Women,
yea Ladies and Gentlewomen, were tyed and coupled together like Bea≈øts and ‚Ä¢ ogs, and ≈øent into the Woods to be ravi≈øhed, and for making re≈øi≈øtance, they had their cloaths ≈øtript off, their Bodies whipt, and their ears cut off, and in this deplorable po≈øture were ≈øent home again; The Souldiers and Crabats got many Thou≈øand head of Cattel together and what bea≈øt ≈øoever did not readily follow them, they killed them, le≈øt they ≈øhould ≈øerve ≈øome Hereticks; many other horrid Barbari≈øms were committed by them, as if they had believed that a Countrey was never throughly conquered, till it were utterly de≈øtroyed by Sword and Fire.

L. In 1633. March 6. about 8 a Clock in the Evening over the Town of Bibrach two long ≈øwords were ≈øeen in the Air, one Fiery, and the other red as blood; many fierce encounters happened about this time and place between the Swedes and Imperiali≈øts, Count Horn the Swedi≈øh Field Mar≈øhal killing near fix hundred Crabats, and as many more Spani≈øh and Italian Souldiers who came to aid the Emperor, peri≈øhed by Cold, Famine and Sword by the way, that betwixt ∆≤lm and Bibrach a thou≈øand dead Carca≈øes were found, ≈øo that a third part of the Army were lo≈øt; ≈øome Months after, four Regiments of the Imperiali≈øts were ≈øurprized and killed by the Swedes betwixt this Town and I≈øne; and ≈øix hundred other Imperiali≈øts being abroad were al≈øo taken, and mo≈øt of them ≈ølain. In March 1634, Gu≈øtavus Horn be≈øieged the City of Bibrach, wherein were thirteen hundred men, offering the Imperial Governour good conditions upon his fir≈øt approach, which being refu≈øed, he battered the Town ≈øo long with his Ordnance, that he won the Enemies works, and made a breach into the Walls. Then the Governour ≈øending out a Trumpet, de≈øired rea≈øonable Terms, or el≈øe he would defend it to the la≈øt man, and threatning fir≈øt of all to blow up all the Prote≈øtant Citizens, whom he had already lockt up in the Town-hou≈øe, and into a Cellar; But having
already refu≈øed fair ofters, the Swedes denyed them now, and prepared all things ready for another a≈ø≈øault, advancing toward the Breach, when at the ≈øame in≈øtant, the Prote≈øtant Mini≈øters with ≈øeveral Women came out of the Town, making mo≈øt pitiful Lamentation to the Swedi≈øh General, ≈øignifying that it would certainly co≈øt them all their Lives, becau≈øe the Townhou≈øe was already undermined, and the Mine filled with Powder, and that they fearfully expected to be blown up immediately. Out of Commi≈øeration therefore to the≈øe poor people, another Agreement was offered to the Governour, and Liberty granted them to march out with their Swords only, which was accepted, and the Prote≈øtants thereby ≈øaved.

LI. In 1634 June 23. another Prodigy happened at Dre≈øden in Saxony; About five a Clock in the Evening the Sun fir≈øt appeared white as Snow, and then ≈øuddenly became dark as if covered by a Mi≈øt; It appeared fir≈øt in the form of a Crown, and then like a Feather, and then red as blood, in which po≈øture it continued for about half an hour, and then returned to its natural ≈øhape, but retained its ≈øanguine colour till it went down, and the Moon at her ri≈øing retained the ≈øame bloody A≈øpect, till ≈øhe was no longer ≈øeen in that Horri≈øon; About the ≈øame time at Berlin in the Marqui≈øate of Brandenburg it rained blood and brim≈øtone; and the next year in November, at Itz ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ o a Town in Hol≈øiein it rained thick blood, who≈øe drops being u≈øed as Ink, repre≈øented true natural blood in writing; It is ≈øcarce credible how many bloody Conflicts and Encounters happened between the≈øe two Countreys, the ≈øame year, and the next following; but more e≈øpecially that ≈øore and bloody Battel at Wit≈øtock, wherein ≈øeven Thou≈øand Imperiali≈øts were ≈ølain by the Swedes, ≈øix whole Regiments being wholly cut off, with ≈øeveral great Commanders; Fifteen Hundred Pri≈øoners, Fourteen Pieces of Ordnance, and Eight Thou≈øand Waggons were al≈øo left to the Swedi≈øh Conqueror; Of the Swedes likewi≈øe were a Thou≈øand
≈ølain upon the place of Battel. In the ≈øame year, 1634. July 24. at Melnick where the Saxon Army quartered, there was a ≈øtrange Apparition in the Air, which was thus related by Eye-witne≈ø≈øes; About Evening, when the Elector of Saxonys Chaplain was at Prayers, there appeared a ≈øign in the sky like a fiery Beam, and a while after, another in the form of a Scepter fiery red, ju≈øt over the Hou≈øe where he was Preaching, a≈ø≈øoon as Sermon was ended, and the Chaplain had pronounced Amen, the ≈øign vani≈øhed out of ≈øight; After this the ≈øame Apparition was ≈øeen again of divers others; That year, and ≈øome others following, the Crabats like Vermine in a warren, ran≈øacked, plundred and pillaged what places ≈øoever they came to, ≈øparing neither Churches, Cloy≈øters, nor Noble mens Hou≈øes, but robbed and di≈ømembred the Countrey people, ravi≈øhed the Women, defloured the Maids, burnt the Villages and Towns, and committed all manner of mi≈øchievous In≈øolencies and Villanies.

LII. About this time Man and Bea≈øt and Fowls of the Air all ≈øeemed now to be at irreconcileable difference, and Germany was the Stage wherein they acted their Tragedies; At He≈ø≈øen in March 1635. there met together two Armies of ≈øtrange Birds, which fought as it were in a ≈øet Battel; And near Straubinge upon the River of Danube multitudes of Dogs had their Rendevouz, who fought ≈øo furiou≈øly, that all the Neighbourhood were affrighted at the Prodigy; And as if they would admit of no Agreement, but ≈øuch as plea≈øed them≈øelves, when the Governour of Ratisbone had ≈øent out again≈øt them four Companies of his Foot Souldiers, with Muskets, and other Arms to a≈ø≈øault and ≈ølay them, they left their ho≈øtility among them≈øelves, and joyned together again≈øt the Common Enemy, falling upon the Souldiers, and in de≈øpight of their ≈øhot and weapons, killed and devoured nine of them. many hundred miles, even to Smyrna and Con≈øtantinople, and all the Shoars and Coa≈øts were filled therewith; The fury of this Burning wa ‚Ä¢ greate≈øt for the fir≈øt two Moneths, which cau≈øed the Neighbour Sea to bubble like a boyling Pot, and night and day huge Globes and Flakes of Fire, and exceeding thick ≈ømoak mounted up to the Heavens; which if at any time it was carryed by contrary winds to any places near at hand, be≈øides a mo≈øt grievous ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ink, it brought certain de≈øtruction upon Birds and Bea≈øts, yea, upon men them≈øelves; As it happened in October and November this year, that fifty Husbandmen mi≈øerably peri≈øhed thereby, be≈øides an innumerable multitude of Birds, Sheep, Oxen, and A≈ø≈øes; The like happened to nine Mariners, who pa≈ø≈øing that way in their ≈øhip by night, after 3 days were all found half burnt, and were buried in the I≈øland Nio three≈øcore miles from Santorin; But the other 4 months (for it flamed ≈øix in all) though that Helli≈øh Hearth or Furnace abated much of its vigour and fierce heat, and could ≈øcarce lift it ≈øelf above the Waves, yet it ≈øtill ≈øeemed to ca≈øt out Pumice ≈øtones, and to be labouring to form a new I≈øland which though it does not yet appear above Water yet in a calm Sea, it is ob≈øerved to be very ≈øhallow thereabout, the Water being in that place not above eight Cubits deep.

LXXI. In 1651. The River of Sein, which runs through Paris in France ≈øwelled ≈øo much, that all the Hou≈øes near it were in danger to have been ruined thereby, and very much hurt was done; The ≈øame year, March 4, the day before the Burial of the late Prince of Orange, a full Tyde of the Sea broke the Dam or Bank of St. Anthony in Holland, and overflowed all that part which is called Diemer Meer; There happened likewi≈øe thereby, very great damage in North-Holland, but at Am≈øterdam the water grew ≈øo high, that the People were compelled to go in Boats through the Streets, be≈øides which, it came into
their Cellars and Warehou≈øes, thereby ≈øpoyling a va≈øt quantity of Merchandi≈øes to the value of many Tuns of Gold. The ≈øame year Sept. 14, a Prodigious Judgment happened at Bi ‚Ä¢ boa in Spain, whereof I have a Letter by me written by a Merchant of good credit (≈øaith Mr. Clark) which thus relates it. Sir I pre≈øume that before this comes to your hands, you will hear of Gods great Judgment upon this To ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ which hath cau≈øed ≈øuch a de≈øtruction as is impo≈ø≈øible to bed ‚Ä¢ ≈øcribed, and at pre≈øent 'tis not throughly known what damage it hath done; upon the eighth of this Moneth it plea≈øed God (not by any extraordinary rains from Heaven to our thinking) to open the Mountains like Fountains, and to cau≈øe the Sea≈øo to ≈øwell, that in le≈øs than four hours it overflowed the Town throughout ≈øixteen foot high, which prevented us not only from ≈øaving our Goods, but al≈øo with great hazard of our lives have we e≈øcaped; yet many lo≈øt their Lives with great de≈øtruction both of the Hou≈øes and Walls; For my own part I feared my life, for my hou≈øe trembled under me extreamly, ≈øo that not only my ≈øelf, but my whole Family had been de≈øtroyed, had it continued but a ≈ømall time longer, though the Water ebbed not for Twenty four hours; Many Iron Mills were de≈øtroyed, many Thou≈øand Loads of Charcoal were carryed away, many bags of Wool ≈øpoiled; All their Shops with their Goods were much damaged; God knows the trouble we underwent, and ≈øtill I am every day in the mud half my height, looking after my Goods, and am fain to keep many men digging to find them, and am looking out for bread to maintain my Family; a little Chicken co≈øts us two ≈øhillings in Spani≈øh Plate; In brief, neither Hor≈øe, Mule, Hog, nor any other Living Creature that goes upon the ground hath e≈øcaped drowning, but only ≈øuch as fled to the tops of the Mountains, The de≈øtruction and lo≈ø≈øes of ‚Ä¢ his Town are un≈øpeakable, the very pavement and ground being carryed away at lea≈øt Ten Foot deep, and the River hath altered its Chanel; The fir≈øt work that we now ≈øet upon (by command of Authority) is to throw away the Fi≈øh which the water brought with it, which being tainted, ≈ømells ≈øo abominably, that we fear it will bring the Plague
among≈øt us, but we hope by to morrow night to throw it all into the River, and thereby be rid of this ≈øtink, and our next work mu≈øt be to clean≈øe the River.

LXXII. In 1652, There was a great Eclip≈øe of the Sun, and Two Eclip≈øes of the Moon: A Two handed Sword was ≈øeen in the Air in Che≈øhire, and Armies of men encountring each other, appeared in the North, a Comet was vi≈øible in the Signs Gemini and Taurus from December 11, to the 30. This year the Engli≈øh ≈øubdued Scotland, and beat the Dutch at Sea; They beat the French at Sea this year al≈øo; The Engli≈øh Parliament, firnamed the Long, are turned out of Doors by their own Army. In 1653, Oliver Cromwell a private Gentleman by Birth, but then General of the Army, a≈ø≈øumes the Government of Great Britain by the Title of Lord Protector of England, Scotland and Ireland; The King of the Romans, and the Pope in two years after dye; ≈øtrange and unheard of Alterations in Law and Government here in England, new Courts of Ju≈øtice, Council of State, Major Generals. In 1654 was another Eclip≈øe of the Sun, and an Earthquake in the We≈øt of England; Apparitions are vi≈øible in the Air in the North of England; A very great Rain falls in Bohemia; At this time the Engli≈øh take Jamaica, and make War with Spain. The Engli≈øh and Swedes unite; In 1655. Ca≈øtles, Cities and Towns appear in the Air in England, and ≈øeem to be be≈øieged, the different Actions and Ge≈øtures of Men, both Commanders and Souldiers being plainly vi≈øible; This year Cardinal Gui≈øi is made Pope by the Title of Innocent the 10. The Polanders are routed by the Swedes: In 1656, An Earthquake happened in Che≈øhire, doing much harm, ≈øinking the Ground, and rending up many Trees by the Roots, to the great damage of the Countrey. In November a fiery Dragon was ≈øeen in the Air in Scotland; This year the Engli≈øh land in Flanders, and take Mardike from the Spaniards, they become angry thereat, and Wars between them grow high;
The King of Denmark was twice invaded by the King of Sweden; There fell ≈øuch abundance of Rain at Vienna in Germany, that the River Danubius ≈øwelling above its banks, the violence of the Waters broke down all the Bridges, and mo≈øt of their Mills; Yea, the Water came into their Suburbs, called, The Jews Suburbs, drowning many Per≈øons, and carrying away a very great number of Cattel, and did ≈øo great mi≈øchief to the Countrey that the lo≈øs was thought ine≈øtimable, there being ≈øixteen Towns and Villages ≈øwept away by the Flood. Gadbury de Comet.

LXXIII. In 1658, A great Whale came up to Greenwich near London, a thing ≈øeldom known before; This year Dunkirk was taken by the Engli≈øh; Sir Henry Slingsby and Dr. Heuit being condemned by an High Court of Ju≈øtice as they called it, were beheaded at Towerhill, and Sept. 3. following, which u≈øed to be a great day of Triumph in Olivers Court for two great Victories at Dunbar and Worce≈øter, was turned into a day of Mourning by the Death of their Protector who dyed about 4 or 5 a Clock that day; and Richard Cromwel confidently ≈øucceeds him in the Government, as if it had been his ju≈øt due; Nay ≈øome People in England ≈øend ≈øuch ≈øugred Addre≈ø≈øes to him, that he believed him≈øelf to be what they flatteringly ≈øtiled him: The King of Sweden lo≈øes much this year and dyes. In 1659, there was a very great Inundation in Holland, which overflowed Thirty Six Thou≈øand Acres of Ground: Al≈øo a great Eclip≈øe of the Sun in Scorpio, November 4. Lofty and ≈øtrange unwonted Winds, In May 1659, the Long Parliament returned, and turned out Richard Cromwell, but were ≈øoon after turned out them≈øelves by Lambert and the Army; A Committee of ≈øafety is ≈øet up; The L. General Monk being troubled to behold the Confu≈øions of the Engli≈øh Proceedings, marched out of Scotland, and after the Committee of Safety was fallen, brings in the ≈øecluded Members of the Long Parliament, who ≈øoon after di≈ø≈øolve them≈øelves, and call
another Parliament who re≈øtore His Royal Maje≈øty King Charles 2. to His ju≈øt Rights and Priviledges, whom God pre≈øerve with a Long and Happy Reign over us. Gadbury of Prodigies.

LXXIV. In 16 ‚Ä¢ 0. Feb. 20. At Dantzick in Poland, when the Sun was going down, there were ≈øeen ≈øeven Suns together very di≈øtinctly in the Heavens, three of them coloured, and three white, be≈øides the True Sun it ≈øelf, about which was a Circle much like a Rainbow. In 1661. Jan. 28. There is a Relation that near Wor≈øup in Nottingham≈øhire there was an appearance of a gallant Troop of Hor≈øe marching, which a Ju≈øtice of Peace having notice of, related to a Per≈øon of Honour, thinking them to be real Men and Hor≈øes, but upon a ≈øtrict inquiry, it was concluded to be only an Apparition; The ≈øame Relation ≈øays about that time, there happened a ≈øtrange and dreadful ≈øtorm of Hail at Northampton, and fire mingled with the hail in ≈øome places, and that it did run upon the ground in great ≈øheets of Fire for a con≈øiderable way together: It fell upon ≈øome part of Wellinborough Town in Northampton≈øhire: Upon February 18. this year very early in the morning began a dreadful ≈øtorm of Wind accompanied with Thunder, Lightning, Hail and Rain, which killed divers Per≈øons by the fall of Hou≈øes and Chimneys, and did very great damage in many places of England. In 1662, about ≈øix a Clock in the Evening, there appeared (≈øaith my Author) in the Heavens near Dover, on the South-≈øide of the Town, a fiery Meteor in the form of an En≈øign and Banner, broad at one end, and narrow at the other, according to the Judgment of the Spectators about 14 yards in length, it was of a fiery red colour, and flew with great ≈øwiftne≈øs from about the Seamark called the Devils drop toward Dover Ca≈øtle, and ≈øo over the Ca≈øtle about a mile in length, winding in its motion, and then gradually vani≈øhe. This was atte≈øted by the Spectators them≈øelves.

LXXV. In 1664. About the beginning of December a Comet appeared in Europe, the body whereof was very large, and its Tail of a very great length, it pointed We≈øtward both as it aro≈øe and as it ≈øate, and this con≈øtantly from the beginning of its appearance to the time of its vani≈øhing; They writ from Edenborough, that it was very remarkable in that it had a ≈øtream i≈ø≈øuing from the ≈øide of it like a red flame out of the mouth of a Furnace, and Mr. Gadbury relates that a Letter which he received from Cranfeild in Bedford≈øhire gives an Account that upon December 27. not far from the Comet was the appearance of a blue and purple colour, all full of Leprous Spots, it was round, and as big as five Moons; not long before this, ≈øaith Mr. Gadbury, we had news of the ≈øhape of a black Coffin ≈øeen in the Air at Hamburg, and other parts in Germany and Flanders; And the very day that the la≈øt Prodigy was ≈øeen, ≈øaith he, I met with a Letter in our News-books dated from Erford in Germany, Decemb. 27. the Contents whereof were the≈øe; We have had our part here of the Comet as well as other places, be≈øides which, here have been other terrible Apparitions and noi≈øes in the Air, as Fires and Sounds of Canon and Masket-≈øhot, and here has likewi≈øe appeared ≈øeveral times the re≈øemblance of a black man, who has made our Sentinels to quit and run away from their Po≈øts; Now, ≈øaith he, though I have no great Faith in Apparitions of this Nature, as knowing that Melancholy heads by the ≈øtrength of Fancy and Imagination, may conceit they ≈øee ≈øuch things that really are not; yet when ≈øuch Fancies ≈øhall really po≈ø≈øe≈øs the General Opinion, it is to be pre≈øumed that ≈øomething more than common, will befall mankind, and our fears do ≈øeem to prepare us for the embraces of that mi≈øchief we dread. This year began a War with the Hollanders and His Maje≈øties Fleet off Port≈ømouth took an hundred and twelve Ships ≈ømall and great from the Dutch, mo≈øt of which were adjudged Lawful Prize.

LXXVI. And here I cannot omit what I find related in the Hi≈øtory of Ceilon an I≈øland in the Ea≈øt-Indies, publi≈øhed by Captain Robert Knox, who was a Captive there for near Twenty years; It happened, ≈øaith he that in December 1664. there was a dangerous Rebellion in this Countrey again≈øt their King, about which time there appeared a fearful Blazing Star; Ju≈øt at the in≈øtant of this Ri≈øing the Star was right over our heads, and one thing I very much wondred at, that whereas before this In≈øurrection the Tail ≈øtood away toward the We≈øt, from whence this Rebellion ≈øprung, yet the very night after, for I well ob≈øerved it, the Tail was turned and ≈øtood away toward the Ea≈øt, and by degrees it dimini≈øhed quite away; At this time I ≈øay, the People of this Land having been long and ≈øore oppre≈ø≈øed by this Kings unrea≈øonable and cruel Government, contrived a Plot again≈øt him: He u≈øed to ≈øhed a great deal of blood without the lea≈øt Rea≈øon, his Cruelty appearing both in the Tortures and painful deaths which he inflicted, and in the extents of his puni≈øhments in de≈øtroying whole Families for the mi≈øcarriage of one Per≈øon; For when he is di≈øplea≈øed with any, he does not always command to kill them outright, but fir≈øt to torment them, which is done by cutting and pulling away their fle≈øh with Pincers, burning them with hot Irons clapt to them to make them confe≈øs their Confederates, whereby they many times confe≈øs more than they ever ≈øaw or knew to be rid of their Torments; After Confe≈ø≈øion he ≈øometimes commands to hang their two hands about their necks, and to make them eat their own fle≈øh, and Mothers to eat their own Children, and ≈øo to lead them through the City in publick view to terrifie all, to the place of Execution, the Dogs following to eat them; who are ≈øo accu≈øtomed to it, that ≈øeeing a Pri≈øoner led away, they follow after; At the place of Execution, there are ≈øome always ≈øticking upon Poles, others hanging up in Quarters upon Trees, be≈øides what
lye killed by Elephants on the ground, or by other ways; His wrath is not appea≈øed (as aforementioned) by the Execution of the Malefactor, but oft times he puni≈øheth all his Generation, it may be he kills them altogether, or gives them all away for Slaves; ≈øo far is he from regarding the good of his Countrey, that he rather endeavours the de≈øtruction thereof, for being now between ≈øeventy and eighty years old, therefore Nature tells him he mu≈øt leave it; However there is no love lo≈øt between the King and his People, which occa≈øioned them to enter into the afore≈øaid Con≈øpiracy again≈øt him; The De≈øign was to a≈ø≈øault the Kings Court in the night, and to ≈ølay him, and make the Prince his Son King, He being then about 15 years of Age, and was with his Mother the Queen in the City of Cande; The time appointed to Act it was Decemb. 20. 1664, at twelve a Clock at night, and having got about two hundred men, (not needing any more.) ≈øince they had ≈øo many Confederates at Court, in the dead of the night, they came marching into the City of Nillemby where the King then was, The Captain of the Watch was thought to be of their Party, but if he were not, it was not in his power to re≈øi≈øt them, however he was afterward executed for it, Being entred the City, they ha≈øtened down to the Court, and fell upon the Great men who lay then without the Palace, upon the Guard; Many who were not intru≈øted with the De≈øign were killed, and tho≈øe that could make their e≈øcape, got in unto the King, who was ≈øecured only with a Clay wall thatched, which was all his ≈øtrength; yet the≈øe People were afraid to a≈ø≈øault his Per≈øon, lying ≈øtill till the morning; At which time the King made his e≈øcape unto the Mountains with only Fifty Per≈øons, There were ≈øome Hor≈øes went with him, but the ways were ≈øo bad, that he could not ride; They were fain to drive an Elephant before him to break the way through the Woods, that the King with his Followers might pa≈øs. As he fled, the Con≈øpirators
pur≈øued him, but at a great di≈øtadce for fear of ≈øome exceellent Fowling Pieces which he had with him, and ≈øo he got ≈øafe to the Mountain Gauluda about 15 miles off, where many of the Inhabitants thereabout re≈øorted to him; But if the Rebel Party had been re≈øolute, who were the greater number, even almo≈øt all the Kingdom, this Hill could not have ≈øecured him, but they might have driven him from thence, there being many ways by which they might have a≈øcended.

The People having thus driven away, the old King marched away to the City of Cande, and proclaimed the Prince to be King, telling us Engli≈øh, that what they had done was not ra≈øhly, but upon good Con≈øideration and advice, the King by his evil Government having occa≈øioned it, who went about to de≈øtroy both them and their Countrey; As in detaining Amba≈ø≈øadors; hindering of all Trade, making Pri≈øoners of all people that come upon his Land, and killing his Subjects and their Children, not ≈øuffering them to enjoy, nor to ≈øee their Wives; And that all this was contrary to rea≈øon, and as they were informed to the Government of other Countreys; The Prince being young and tender, and having never been out of the Pallace, nor ever ≈øeen any but tho≈øe that attended on his Per≈øon, was affinghted to ≈øee ≈øo many coming, and bowing down to him, and telling him that he was King, and his Father was fled into the Mountains; neither did he ≈øay or act any thing, as not owning the bu≈øine≈øs, or el≈øe not knowing what to ≈øay or do; This much di≈øcouraged the Rebels, to ≈øee they had no Thanks for their pains, and ≈øo all things ≈øtood till, D ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ emo. 25. 1664, at which time they intended to march and fall upon the old King; But in the mean time the Kings Si≈øter flyes away with the Prince from the City, into the Countrey near the King, which ≈øo amazed the Rebels, that the Money, Cloth and plunder which they had taken, and were going to di≈øtribute
to ≈øtrangers to joyn with them, they ≈øcattered about the Town, and fled away; Others of their Company ≈øeeing the bu≈øine≈øs was overthrown, to make amends for their former Fact, revolted and fell upon their Con≈øorts, killing and taking Pri≈øoners all they could; The People were now all up in Arms again≈øt each other, killing whom they plea≈øed, (only ≈øaying they were Rebels) and taking their Goods; By this time a great Man had drawn out his Souldiers into the Field, and declared for the old King, and ≈øo went to ≈øeize the Rebels that were ≈øcattered abroad; but under≈øtanding they were all fled, and no wh ‚Ä¢ le Party or Body left to re≈øi≈øt him, he marched into the City, killing all he could catch; And ≈øo all revolted, and came back to the King again, whil≈øt he only lay ≈øtill upon his Mountain; The King needed to take no care to ≈øeize or execute the Rebels, for they them≈øelves out of their zeal to him, and to make amends for what was pa≈øt, impri≈øoned, and killed all they met, the Plunder being their own; This continued 8 of 10 days, which the King hearing of, commanded to kill no more, but only to impri≈øon them till examination, which was not ≈øo much to ≈øave the Innocent, as that he might torment the Rebels, and make them confe≈øs their Confederates, for he ≈øpared none that ≈øeemed guilty, and ≈øome to this day lye chained in Pri≈øon, being ≈øeque≈øtred of all their E≈øtates, and beg for their Living; The King could not be in≈øen≈øible but that it was his rigorous Government which occa≈øioned this Rebellion, yet amended it not in the lea≈øt, but like Rehoboam added yet more to the Peoples yoke: And being thus ≈øafely rein≈øtated in his Kingdom again, and ob≈øerving that the Life of his Son gave incouragement to the Rebellion, he re≈øolved for the future to prevent it by taking him away, and about a year after, his Son being ≈øick, the Hing takes this Opportunity to di≈øpatch him, by pretending to ≈øend Phy≈øick to him to cure him, but was really Poy≈øon, which ≈øoon made an end of him; The People hearing
of the death of the Prince, according to the Cu≈øtom of that Countrey when any of the Royal Blood dye, came all in General toward the City where he was, with black, or el≈øe very dirty Cloths, which is their mourning, the men all bare-headed, the Women with their hair loo≈øe and hanging about their Shoulders to mourn and lament for the Death of their young Prince; which the King hearing of, ≈øent them word, That ≈øince it was not his Fortune to live to ≈øit on the Throne after him, and Reign over the Land, it would be but in vain to mourn and a great trouble and hindrance to the Countrey, and their voluntary good will was taken in as good part us the mourning it ≈øelf, and ≈øo di≈ømi≈øt the A≈ø≈øembly, and burned the Princes dead body without Ceremonies or Solemnities; but one thing there is that argues him guilty of Imprudence, and horrible Ingratitude, that mo≈øt of tho≈øe who went along with him when he fled, of who≈øe Loyalty he had ≈øuch ample Experience he hath ≈øince cut off, and that with extream Cruclty too; In Feornary two years after, there appeared in this Countrey another Comet or Stream in the We≈øt, with the head of it under the Horizon, much like that ≈øeen in England in 1680. The ≈øight of this did much daunt both King and People, having ≈øo lately felt the ≈øad Event of a Blazing Star; The King ≈øent men to the highe≈øt Mountains in the Land to look if they could perceive the head of it, which they could not, it being ≈øtill under the Horizon; This continued vi≈øible about a Month, and by that time was ≈øo dimini≈øhed as not to be ≈øeen; But there were no remarkable Pa≈ø≈øages en≈øued upon it.

LXXVII. About five or ≈øix nights after the extinction of the fir≈øt Comet which was ≈øeen in England, and in the ≈øame Moneth of December another Comet was vi≈øible, which continued till the middle of January following, it was much le≈øs than the former, ≈øeeming about the bigne≈øs of an ordinary
Trencher Plate, about 8 Inches over, and had prickly Rays di≈øper≈øed round about it; In April 1665, following, a Third Comet was ≈øeen much of the Nature and colour of the fir≈øt, only a little more Jovial; This year, June 3. A great Victory was obtained by His Maje≈øties Fleet under his Royal Highne≈øs the Duke of York again≈øt the whole Dutch Fleet, wherein above Thirty Capital Ships were taken and de≈øtroyed, and near Eight Thou≈øand men killed and taken Pri≈øoners; A great Plague began in London, and this year there dyed in all ninety ≈øeven thou≈øand three hundred and ≈øix, whereof of the Plague ≈øixty eight thou≈øand five hundred ninety ≈øix; In February this year, there was a great Tempe≈øt, accompanied with Thunder, Lightning, and an Earthquake in divers places; at which time the ≈øtately Spire of Trinity Church in Coventry fell down, and demoli≈øhed a great part of the Church, killing only one man; and in Hamp≈øhire a Ju≈øtice of Peace riding by the way, was ≈ølain and burnt by Lightning; In Augu≈øt, 1666, Sir Robert Holmes de≈øtroyed above one hundred and fifty Sail of Dutch Ships at the Fly in Holland, and burnt the Town of Bandaris upon the I≈øland of Schelling, containing at lea≈øt a Thou≈øand Hou≈øes. XCI. In 1682. Oct. 5. A ≈øtrange Mon≈øter was born at Exeter in Devon≈øhire, having two perfect heads, one ≈øtanding right as it ≈øhould, the other being in the right Shoulder, with Eyes, No≈øe, Ears, Mouth, and Tongue to each head proper, it had but two Arms and Hands, and two Legs and Feet, all in good, and comely ≈øhapes, they which were at the delivery ≈øay, that they were two as hando≈øme Faces as ever they ≈øaw, it was living when born, but ≈øoon expired, only giving one ≈øigh at its departure; It was ≈øoon buried, but after taken up again, and expo≈øed to the view of numerous Spectators, to the great advantage of the Parents.

Thus have I briefly run over abundance of Strange Prodigies, Apparitions, and Accidents which have happened in the Heavens, Earth and Sea in ≈øeveral Countreys for near Seventeen Hundred years pa≈øt, but as to the Application of the Effects of divers of them to particular Per≈øons or Places I have barely collected mo≈øt of them from that noted A≈øtrologer Mr. John Gadbury in his Treati≈øe of Prodigies, and his Di≈øcour≈øe of the three Comets in 1664, and 1665. Though, as an Ingenious Gentleman lately ob≈øerves, there may be much doubt and que≈øtion whether there be any great certainty in the≈øe Predictions, ≈øince they have been judged ≈øometimes to portend evil as well as good, for as he ≈øays, Though that Comet which ≈øome interpreted to pre≈øage Luthers preaching again≈øt Indulgences, and the Reformation which followed, be≈øpoke evil it may be to the Popes Kitchen, yet it was certainly the dawning of the Ble≈ø≈øed Light of the Go≈øpel to the We≈øtern Parts of Chri≈øtendom; But however, (as he adds) if the terrorand rarene≈øs of the≈øe Prodigies do upon any Account what≈øoever mind us of our Mortality, and prepare us for our end (as it hath effected upon ≈øome in former Ages) or to reflect upon our ownor the publick Crimes, which may call down Gods; vengeance upon us, and to implore his mercy and fors
bearance toward us, it may be very u≈øeful and profitable, for ≈øure it is, this Age has need enough of Repentance, and without a Comet, we want not abundant Notices and Warnings that if we do not for≈øake our horrid enormities, we cannot long e≈øcape the ≈øignal vengeance of Heaven. But, ≈øaith he, the making u≈øe of them, thereby to read the de≈øtiny of Kings, Nations and Governments is Irrational, Fanta≈øtical, and Heatheni≈øh, unbecoming either a Man, or a Chri≈øtian, and therefore in≈øtead of any dreadful Pre≈øages, The Ble≈ø≈øing of the Almighty be upon the whole I≈ørael of God, Amen.

I cannot better conclude this Subject than by in≈øerting the following Letter, written by a famous Prelate of our Church, inferior to no man of this Age, either for Piety or Learning, wherein he declares his thoughts concerning the Comet in Augu≈øt la≈øt, 1682, which ≈øeems fully to comprize all that can be ≈øaid by the wi≈øe≈øt of Mortals concerning Comets. The Letter is as followeth.

My good Friend, It ≈øeems your Philomathematici (as your Almanack- ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ kers u≈øually „Äà‚óä„Äâ them≈øelves) and A≈øtrologers i ‚Ä¢

„Äà‚óä„Äâ I ≈øhall tell you mine, though (may be) it may ≈øignify as little as theirs when they do declare it. 1. Then (in the General) It has been the opinion of „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ that all Comets portend ≈øome „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . Nations, Countreys, Cities, or particular Per≈øons; „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Greeks „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , All Comets are fore-runners of ≈øome Calamities; And a Latin Poet and a Pagan ‚Ä¢ ould ≈øay, Nunquam furilibus excanduit ignibus ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ her. 2. But in particular, I believe (and I think there is good rea≈øon for it) there are three things concerning Comets which may, and other three things which neither are, nor certainly can be known; For in≈øtance, 1. Their Motion 2. Their Magnitude. 3. Their Exit and vani≈øhing, how they come to di≈øappear, and what becomes of them afterward; The≈øe things none of your A≈øtrologers and Star-gazers do, or (by any ground in Nature or Scripture, Rea≈øon or Revelation) can certainly know; They may gue≈øs, and ≈øo may you and I, and it may be as well as they, but 'tis only Conjecture, not Science, they having no ground from which they can certainly conclude their Conjectures to be true; Nay I do confidently and truly add, (and there is evident Rea≈øon for it) that neither the Pope, notwith≈øtanding his Infallibility, nor the Devil notwith≈øtanding all his Subtilty, can certainly know what any Comet does particularly portend, unle≈øs it plea≈øe God, who only knows to di≈øcover and reveal it to them.

div.head: The Surprizing Miracles of Art, or an Account of the most Magnificent Buildings, and Curious Inventions and Rarities in all Ages. Part II.
div.p:
HAving related a multitude of Miracles and Prodigies of Nature. I ≈øhall now proceed to tho≈øe of Art; The Chine≈øes look upon them≈øelves as the wi≈øe≈øt People upon the face of the Earth, they u≈øe therefore to ≈øay, That they ≈øee with both Eyes, and all other Nations but with one only, and thereupon they boa≈øt, though I know not with what Truth and Ju≈øtice that the mo≈øt famous Inventions which have been ≈øo lately known to us in Europe, have been no Strangers to them for many Ages pa≈øt; however I ≈øhall relate
what are mo≈øt ob≈øervable both in the≈øe and other Nations. It is likewi≈øe recorded, that Augu≈øtus Cae≈øar having ≈øeveral ways adorned and fortifyed the City of Rome, putting it into a condition of bravery and ≈øecurity for after times, he thereupon gloried, That he found Rome of brick, and left it of Marble; and certainly nothing makes more for the ju≈øt Glory of a Prince than to leave his Dominions in better State than he found them; Yet the va≈øt Expences of ≈øome Princes and People had been more truly commendable, and their mighty works more really glorious, had they therein con≈øulted more of the Publick good, and le≈øs of their own O≈øtentation; However it may not be unplea≈øant, nor unprofitable to de≈øcribe them, and likewi≈øe to relate the mo≈øt curious Inventions and Rarities in all Ages even to the≈øe times, which have been more favourable to Learning than the former, and wherein Arts have been thereby improved to the height;

1. But fir≈øt concerning Buildings, the mo≈øt famous ≈øtructure we fir≈øt read of, was immediately after the Univer≈øal Deluge, or Noah's Flood, for Nimrod the Son of Chus, the Son of Cham, per≈øwaded the People to ≈øecure them≈øelves from the like after-claps by building ≈øome ≈øtupendious Edifice, which might re≈øi≈øt the fury of a ≈øecond Deluge; This Coun≈øel was generally imbraced; Heber only and his Family (as the Tradition goes) contradicting ≈øuch an unlawful attempt; But the major part prevailing, the Tower of Babel began to rear its Head of Maje≈øty Five Thou≈øand One Hundred Forty ≈øix Paces from the Ground, having its Ba≈øis and circumference equal to its height: The Pa≈ø≈øage to go up went winding about the out≈øide and was of an exceeding great breadth, there being not only room for Hor≈øes, Carts, and the likemeans of Carriage to meet and turn, but lodgings al≈øo for Man and Bea≈øt; And (as Ver≈ølegan reports) Gra≈øs and Cornfields for their nouri≈øhment; and admirable it is to con≈øider, what multitudes of men there were in the
World in ≈øo ≈øhort a ≈øpace, there being but eight per≈øons that came out of the Ark, and now this Building was carried on by Five Hundred Thou≈øand Men, the Foundation of it was nine miles compa≈øs; But God by the Confu≈øion of Tongues hindred the Proceeding of this Building, one not being able to under≈øtand what his Fellow called for; which Du Bartas wittily de≈øcribes.

q.l: Bring me (quoth one) a Trowel quickly quick,

II. We read in ≈øeveral Ancient Hi≈øtories of The ≈øeven Marvels, or Wonders of the World, The fir≈øt whereof they reckoned to be The Walls of Babylon; This City of Babylon was ≈øeated on the Banks of the River Euphrates, which ran through the mid≈øt of it, over which Semiramuis built a ≈øtrong and ≈øtately Bridge of a mile long, binding each ≈øtone together with clips of Iron fa≈øtened with melted Lead, and is the anciente≈øt City of the World, fir≈øt built by Nimrod in the place appointed for the rai≈øing of the Tower of Babel, and by him made the Imperial Seat of the Chaldea ‚Ä¢
