But la≈øt of all by Ero≈øtratus, who ob≈øerving the Soveraign Magnificence thereof, was re≈øolved to burn it to get him≈øelf a Name; which he did accordingly, but to di≈øappoint him, the Princes of tho≈øe Countreys (as ≈øome Authors affirm) forbid that any man ≈øhould ≈øpeak, write, or record his name, yet all this was to no purpo≈øe, for latter Hi≈øtorians name him, and call him Ero≈øtratas; This glorious Temple was burnt the ≈øame night that Alexander the Great was born, which gave occa≈øion to that witty ≈øcoff, That Diana (who was counted one of the Godde≈ø≈øes of Midwifry) could not attend the Pre≈øervation of her Temple, being then bu≈øied at the birth of ≈øo great a Prince; Some write, that this Temple was afterward rebuilt, much more ≈øumptuous and magnificent than before, and that the Ma≈øter of the work was named Democrates.

7. The ≈øixth Wonder of the World, was the Idol or Image of Jupiter Olympas, which ≈øtood in his Temple at Achaia, between the Cities of Elis and Pi≈øa; This Statue was much renowned as well for artificial per≈øections, and admirable Workman≈øhip as for the greatne≈øs thereof, being no le≈øs than ≈øixty Cubits high, compo≈øed by that excellent workman Phidias of Gold and Ivory, Some ≈øay, that Phidias was taxed with only one imperfection, that he had not proportioned the Image to the bigne≈øs of the Temple, becau≈øe he had made it ≈øitting and ≈øo large, that if the ≈øtanding upright were con≈øidered the Temple would no ways have been able to have contained it; In honour of this Jupiter the Olympicks Games were in≈øtituted by Hercules, and celebrared on the Plains near this City in the year of the World 2757. The exerci≈øes in them were for the mo≈øt part bodily, as running in Chariots, running on foot, wra≈øtling, fighting with Clubs and the like; But yet there repaired thither Orators, Poets, and Mu≈øicians, and all that thought them≈øelves excellent in any laudable quality to make Tryal of their ≈øeveral Abilities, the very cryes who proclaimed the Victories contending who ≈øhould cry loude≈øt, and be≈øt play his part; The rewards given to the Victors were only Garl ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ds of Palm, or ≈øuch ≈ølight remembrances, and yet the Greeks no le≈øs e≈øteemed this ≈ømall ≈øign of Conque≈øt and Honour, than the Romans did their mo≈øt magnificent Triumphs, tho≈øe who were Conquerors therein were met by the Principal Men of the City wherein they lived, and a Pa≈ø≈øage was broken through the main VValls of the Town for their Reception, as if the ordinary Gates were not capable of ≈øo high an honour, or able to afford them entrance; The Judges of the≈øe Games were ≈øome Citizens of Elis appointed for that purpo≈øe; Of the≈øe Games Horace thus writes,
Some in Olympick du≈øt take Pride
Their Chariots and them≈øelves to hide,
Whom the won Mark, and Palm ≈øo priz'd
Like to the Gods hath Eterniz'd.
Such as like heavenly Angels come
With an Elean Garland home.

VIII. The ≈øeventh Wonder of the World was The Tower of Pharos, which ≈øtood in an I≈ø≈øe of that name near the City of Alexandria in Egypt, a mile di≈øtant from the Land, but joyned to the Continent by Cleopatra Queen of Egypt upon this occa≈øion; The Rhodians then Lords of the Sea, u≈øed to exact ≈øome Tribute and acknowledgment out of every I≈øland within tho≈øe Seas, and con≈øequently out of this; Their Amba≈ø≈øadors being ≈øent to Cleopatra to demand this Tribute, ≈øhe detained them with her 7 days, under pretence of celebrating ≈øome ≈øolemn Fe≈øtivals and in the mean time by making huge dams, and banks in the Sea, with incredible charge and ≈øpeed, ≈øhe united Pharos to the ≈øhoar, ≈øo that it was no longer an I≈øland; which fini≈øhed, ≈øhe ≈øent away the Rhodians empty handed, with this witty jeer, That they were to take Toll of the I≈ølands, but not of the Continent; A work of great Rarity and magnificence, both for the bigne≈øs of it, taking up ≈øeven Furlongs of ground, and for that incredible ≈øpeed wherewith it was fini≈øhed; As for the Watch-Tower called Pharos, by the name of the I≈øland, it was built by Ptolomy Philadelphus King of Egypt for the benefit of Saylors, (the Sea on that coa≈øt being very un≈øafe, and full of flats,) to guide them over the Bar of Alexandria, De≈øervedly e≈øteemed one of the Worlds ≈øeven Wonders; It was of a wonderful height, a≈øcended by degrees, and having many Lanthorns on the top, wherein Lights were burned every night flaming like a Beacon for direction to Seamen; It was erected of Marble, marvellous in curious Workman≈øhip, and ≈øcituate upon a Mountain incompa≈ø≈øed with Water, the chief Workman was So≈øtratus, who ingraved on the work this In≈øcription; So≈øtratus of Cnidos, the Son of Dexiphanes to the Gods Protector for the Safeguard of
Saylors; This In≈øcription he covered with Plai≈øter, and thereon ingraved the name and Title of the King who was the Founder; to the end that the Kings name being ≈øoon wa≈øted and wa≈øhed away, his own which was written in Marble might be eternized to Po≈øterity as the Founder thereof. Nigh unto Pharos, Cae≈øar pur≈øuing Pompey into Egyt, and having di≈øcontented Plolomy the King thereof by demanding pay for his Souldiers, Cae≈øars Navy lying here at Anchor, was a≈ø≈øaulted by Achilles one of young Ptolomys Commanders, Cae≈øar him≈øelf being then at Alexandria, but hearing of the skirmi≈øh, he ha≈øtned to Pharos, re≈øolving to ≈øuccour his Navy in Per≈øon; but the Egyptians coming upon him on all fides, he was compelled to leap into the Sea, and ≈øwim for his life, and though to avoid their darts he ≈øometime dived, yet he ≈øtill held his left hand above water, and in it divers books (≈øome ≈øay his Commentaries) which he carryed ≈øafe to his Ships, and incouraging his men, got the Victory; It is ≈øaid, That Egypt hath only two doors, the one by Land, which is the ≈øtrong Town of Pelu≈øium, or Damiata, the other by Water, which is this Pharos. Heylins Co≈ømography, lib. 3.

IX. Having related The ≈øeven Wonders of the World I ≈øhall now proceed to ≈øome other famous Structures, and among them we read of none more magnificent than the Temple of Solomon, but that being at large de≈øcribed in the Holy Scriptures in the Books of the Kings and Chronicles; I ≈øhall therefore rather give a de≈øcription of the City and Temple of Jeru≈øalem as they were, when de≈øtroyed by the Romans aforementioned, Jeru≈øalem was compa≈ø≈øed with a Treble VVall on every ≈øide, ≈øave only that part which was inclo≈øed with inacce≈ø≈øible Vallys, for on that ≈øide it needed only one VVall; It was built upon two Hills, one oppo≈øite to the other, ≈øeparated by a Valley, which was wonderfully repleni≈øhed with Hou≈øes; One of the≈øe Hills whereon ≈øtood the upper part of the City, was far higher and ≈øteeper than the other, which K. David
compa≈ø≈øing with a VVall, called The City of David; On the other Hill, called Acra, ≈øtood the lower part of the City, oppo≈øite whereunto was another Hill lower than that, which at fir≈øt was divided from it by a large Valley, but when the A≈ømonians reigned, they filled up this Valley, and cut down the top of Acra, that it might not hide the Temple; VVithin one of the Valleys was Siloam a Fountain ≈øending forth abundance of clear ≈øweet water; The outmo≈øt VVall by rea≈øon of the Valley about it, and the Rock whereon it ≈øtood was impregnable, being ≈øtrongly built by David, Solomon, and other Kings; A fourth VVall was begun by Agrippa; In humane Rea≈øon had this VVall been fini≈øhed, the City could never have been taken, for the Stones were 20 Cubi ‚Ä¢ s long, and 10 Cubits broad, ≈øo that it could neither have been ea≈øily undermined, nor battered with Engines, but he built this VVall only 10 Cubits high, and then gave it over, fearing le≈øt Claudius Cae≈øar ≈øhould think he de≈øigned to rebel. Yet afterward the Jews rai≈øed this VVall twenty Cubits high, made a battlement two Cubits high, and the Tower three Cubits, in all 24 Cubits high, Be≈øides upon the Wall were three Towers, twenty Cubits broad, and 20 Cubits high, built four≈øquare very ≈øtrongly; within the≈øe Towers were rooms to dwell in, and Ci≈øterns to receive rain water; The third VVall had ninety of the≈øe Towers, and between every Tower were two hundred Cubits ≈øpace, the ≈øecond VVall had 14 Towers, and the old VVall had 60, the compa≈øs of the whole City being 33 Furlongs.

Between the North and We≈øt part of the City upon the outmo≈øt Wall ≈øtood the Tower P≈øephina, which was rai≈øed 70 Cubits high, ≈øo that in a clear day one might from thence di≈øcover Arabia, and the utmo≈øt Confines of Judea, even to the Sea. Ju≈øt oppo≈øite to this, was the Tower Hippicon built by Herod upon the old Wall, which for bigne≈øs, beauty, and ≈øtrength, ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed all others in the World, It had four Corners, each of which was 25 Cubits broad, as many
long, and 30 Cubits high, and in no place hollow; On the top was a Well to receive Rain Water 20 Cubits deep; on the top of all were Hou≈øes 25 Cubits high, divided into many Rooms; Above them were battlements two Cubits, and Turrets three Cubits high, ≈øo that in all it was 85 Cubits high. Herod likewi≈øe built a ≈øecond Tower, in bredth, length and height 40 Cubits, in form of a ≈øquare Pillar all ≈øolid, and not hollow within, and above this a Porch 10 Cubits high, adorned with Turrers and Pinacles; Over the mid≈øt of this Porch he built another Tower, di≈øtingui≈øhed into very hand≈øome rooms, and ≈øumptuous Baths beautified on the top with Turrets and Pinacles, ≈øo that the whole height was near 90 Cubits; La≈øtly he built a third Tower which he called by his Queens name Mariamne, 20 Cubits in height and breadth, all of ≈øolid ≈øtone, not hollow, having more ≈øtately and magnificent Lodgings in it than any of the former, it was in all 5 Cubits high. The≈øe Towers though they were very high, yet by rea≈øon of their ≈øituation they ≈øeemed much higher, for the old Wall whereon they were built ≈øtood upon a Rock which was 30 Cubits high, whereby their height was much increa≈øed, neither were they built of ordinary ≈øtone, but all of white Marble, each Stone being 20 Cubits long, 10 broad, and 5 Cubits thick, which were ≈øo curiou≈øly joyned together, that they ≈øeemed to be all but one ≈øtone; Within the City was the Kings Palace, ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing all in the World for largene≈øs, and curious Workman≈øhip; It was invironed with a Wall 30 Cubits high, adorned with goodly Towers round about, Beautified with Hou≈øes for an hundred of the Nobility‚ñ™ The Variety of the Marble wherewith it was built was admirable, all ≈øorts being therein u≈øed though never ≈øo ≈øcarce to be found; In every room were many Ve≈ø≈øels of Gold and Silver; and ≈øeveral Porches round about adorned with mo≈øt curious Pillars; There were in it very many plea≈øant Walks, adorned with all manner of Trees, and Gardens be≈øet with Fountains,
which ≈øpouted up water on high, and Ci≈øterns beautified with divers brazen Statues from which ran out water continually.

The Temple was built upon a Rocky Mountain, the Plain on the top whereof was at fir≈øt ≈øcarce big enough for the Temple and Court, the Hill being very ≈øteep, but the people every day bringing Earth thither, they at la≈øt made it plain and large enough; and with wonderful Curio≈øity and Labour inclo≈øed the Hill with a Treble Wall, which was not effected in many Ages, with the co≈øt of all the Holy Trea≈øure offered to God from all parts of the World; The Foundations of the Temple were layd three hundred Cubits deep, and in many places more; The ≈øtones thereof were 40 Cubits, the Porches were double, ≈øupported by many ≈øtately Pillars 25 Cubits high, all of one piece of white Marble, the tops of them were of Cedar ≈øo exactly wrought, as a≈øtoni≈øhed the Beholders; The≈øe Porches were 30 Cubits broad, and the compa≈øs of all was ≈øix Furlongs, The Courts were curiou≈øly wrought, and paved with all ≈øorts of ≈øtones. The way to the inward Temple was all inclo≈øed with ≈øtones wrought like Lattice work which were 3 Cubits high of Curious Workman≈øhip; To this there was an a≈øcent by 14 ≈øteps, and above it, was four≈øquare, and inclo≈øed with a Wall by it ≈øelf, 40 Cubits high on the out≈øide, and all covered with ≈øtairs to a≈øcend up to it, and within it was 25 Cubits high, At the top of the 14 ≈øtairs within the Wall, was a level compa≈ø≈øed with a Wall of 300 Cubits which had Gates in it, and between the Gates were Porches oppo≈øite to each other, reaching from the Wall to the Treafury, ≈øupported with mighty Pillars, All the Gates were covered with Plates of Gold and Silver, only one was covered with Corinthian Bra≈øs, which for beauty far excelled the other, dazling and ≈øurprizing the Eyes of the Spectators, In every Gate were two Doors each of them 30 Cubits high, and 15 broad, and on each ≈øide they had ≈øeats 30 Cubits long, and 40 in height, each of
them ≈øupported with 2 Pillars, 12 Cubits thick, only the Gate which was covered with Corinthian Bra≈øs was „Äà‚óä„Äâ Cubits high, and the Gates 40, more richly adorred than the re≈øt; La≈øtly the Holy of Holies, or Sanctum Sanctorum was ≈øcituate in the mid≈øt of all, and had 12 ≈øtairs to go up to it, the fore-part of it was an hundred Cubits high, and as many broad; backward it was 40 Cubits, on each ≈øide it had as it were two ≈øhoulders, ri≈øing up in height 20 Cubits; The fir≈øt Gate was 20 Cubits high, and 25 wide, and had no doors, to ≈øhew, That Heaven was always open, &c. All the ≈øore parts were guilded, and all within was covered with fine gold; The inward part was divided into 2 rooms, whereof the fir≈øt only might be ≈øeen, which was in height 90 Cubits, in length 40, and in breadth 20. Round about the Wall was a golden Vine, whereon hung many Grapes in Clu≈øters all of Gold, every clu≈øter being about ≈øix foot long; It had golden Gates 55 Cubits high, and 16 broad; It had curious hangings of the ≈øame length, admirably wrought with purple, violet, and ≈øcarlet ≈øilk, all the Fabrick was ≈øo exqui≈øitely and richly wrought, that none could po≈ø≈øibly imagine any Workman≈øhip it wanted; For it was all covered with a ma≈ø≈øy plate of pure Gold which a≈øtoni≈øhed the Beholders; The top was all ≈øet with Rods of Gold, ≈øharp like Pikes at the ends, le≈øt Birds ≈øhould ≈øit thereon and defile it, The ≈øtones wherewith it was built were 45 Cubits in length, ≈øix broad, and as many thick; Jo≈øephus Hi≈øt. lib. 6.

Jeru≈øalem was a principal City in Jo≈øua's time, when Adonth ‚Ä¢ zek was King, who was ≈ølain by him, yet did the Jebu≈øites hold it almo≈øt four hundred years after, till David won it, though the Inhabitants did ≈øo much rely on the place, that they boa≈øted their lame and blind men ≈øhould defend it. 2 Sam. 5.6. David having conquered it, ≈øtrengthned it with a Ca≈øtle, and beautified it with many Palaces. And after his time, Solomon inlarged, and further beautified, and fortified
it extreamly. The Pallaces, Gates and Walls could not be matched in all the World; it had an hundred and fifty thou≈øand Inhabitants be≈øides Women and Children; The Trench about it was ≈øixty foot deep, cut out of the Rock, and 250 foot broad, the like ≈øcarce ever heard of; Not long after, Shi≈øhak Kin Aegypt took and ≈øackt it, and became Ma≈øter not only of Solomons
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ es, but of all K. Davids ≈øpoils which he had taken from many Nations. 2 Kings 14. It was again plundred, and part of the Wall broken down by Joas King of I≈ørael in Amazia's Reign. 2 Kings 16. Not long after Ahaz the fifteenth K. of Juda impoveri≈øhed the Temple, to pre≈øent Tiglathpilnezer with the Trea≈øures thereof, and Mana≈ø≈øes lo≈øt what remained. 1 Chron 5. And Nebuchadnezzar laid this glorious City with the Temple, Pallaces, Walls and Towers thereof, even to the Ground. 2 Kings 19. It was built again by Nehemiah, Chap. 12.34. and again the Temple and City were ≈øpoiled by Bugo≈øes Leiutenant to Artaxerxes, Then by Ptolomeus the Fir≈øt; Then by Antiochus Epiphanes; And again by Apollonius his Deputy; After which it was taken by Pompey, and robbed by Cra≈ø≈øus in his Parthian Expedition; yet all the lo≈ø≈øes that the Temple and City ≈øu≈øtained, were repaired by Herod the Great, who inlarged the City, new built the Temple, and adorned it with many ≈øumptuous Works, and left it in a more ≈øtately and glorious condition than it was in the days of Solomon. La≈øtly about 40 years after the Death of Chri≈øt, the ≈øins of the Jews being come to the height, it was de≈øtroyed by Titus the Roman General, who made it ≈øo de≈øolate, that they which ≈øaw it afterward, could ≈øcarce believe there had ever been ≈øuch a City in that place, only he left the 3 Herodian Towers, as well for Lodgings for the Roman Garri≈øons, as to make his Victory more glorious; yet afterwards ≈øome of the de≈øpi≈øed Jews began to build and inhabit ≈øome part of the City; but after 65 years, as aforementioned, when they began to revolt again Aelius Adrianus the Emperor ≈ølew many Thou≈øands
of them, and overthrew the three Towers of Herod with all the re≈øt, not leaving ≈øtone upon another as our Saviour had foretold; But when his fury was appea≈øed, he took one part without the VVall, wherein ≈øtood Mount Calvery and Chri≈øts Sepulcher, and made it a capacious City, which he called after his own name Aelia Capitolia; And in the Gate toward Bethel, he cau≈øed a Sow to be cut in Marble, and ≈øet it in the Front to de≈øpite the Jews, making an Edict, That thenceforth none of them ≈øhould ever enter into that City, not dare ≈øo much as to behold, or look toward it from any high place; Yet the Chri≈øtian Religion flouri≈øhing in Pale≈øtine, it was inhabited by all Nations, e≈øpecially Chri≈øtians, and ≈øo it continued five hundred years; And in 639 it was taken by the Egyptian Saracens, who held it above four hundred years. In 1099 it was regained by Godfrey of Bullein, who being elected King, refu≈øed to be crowned with a Crown of Gold, ≈øince Chri≈øt for whom he fought, was there crowned with Thorns; It continued to him and his Succe≈ø≈øors for 88 years, till in 1197 it was retaken by Saladine King of Aegypt, and la≈øtly in 1517. the Turks beat out the Aegyptians, and hold it to this day, calling it in their Language Cuzumbarec, or The Holy City; Rawleighs Hi≈øt. World.

X. The City of Nineveh as it was more ancient than almo≈øt any other City, ≈øo in greatne≈øs it excelled all tho≈øe that were famous in old time. The Plot or ground of it is ≈øaid to be four hundred and eighty Furlongs; The Walls were in height one hundred foot, and the breadth of them ≈øuch, that three Chariots might meet on the top of them; On the Walls there were Fifteen Hundred Towers, each of them Two Hundred Foot high, it was called Tetrapolis, as being divided as it were into four Cities, Nineveh, Re≈øena, Forum, and Cale, and was reckoned three days Journey in the time of Jonas the Prophet.

11. The Capitol of Rome ≈øeated on the Tarpeian Rock ≈øeemed to contend with Heaven in height, and no doubt but the length and depth were every way an≈øwerable; The exce≈ø≈øive charge that the Emperor Domitian was at in building it, Martial after his flattering manner hath wittily de≈øcribed, and which may be thus tran≈ølated.

q.l: So much has Cae≈øar given the Gods above
That ≈øhould be call it in, and Creditor prove

div.p:
We may partly give a gue≈øs at the Riches and Ornaments of it by this, that there was ≈øpent only upon its gilding above Twelve Thou≈øand Talents; It was all guilded over, not the inner roof only, but the outward covering which was of bra≈øs or Copper, and the doors of it were overlay'd with thick Plates of Gold, which remained to the Reign of Honorius. After the great overthrow of the Romans by the Gauls near the River Allia, tho≈øe that e≈øcaped fled to Rome for ≈øecurity, filling all the City with trouble and fear, but the People not judging them≈øelves ≈øafe there, got all away out of the Town, only a ≈ømall number of the mo≈øt re≈øolute put them≈øelves into the Capitol, re≈øolving to indure all extremities; The re≈øt e≈øcaped to the City of Veios, where a≈ø≈øembling together, they cho≈øe Furius Camillus (whom ≈øome time before they had di≈øobliged) to be their Dictator, but he would not accept of the Dignity unle≈øs the Senators in the Capitol gave their Legal con≈øent thereunto; This was very difficult, becau≈øe the Gauls had environed it round about with their Troops, yet one Pontius undertook this dangerous enterprize, and coming to the River Tyber, he ≈øwom over upon a piece of broad Cork, and landing on the other ≈øide, he went ≈øoftly, that way where he ≈øaw no light, and therefore ≈øuppo≈øed there was no watch kept, and ≈øo climbing up the ≈øteep
craggy rocks, he with much ado got to the top where being e≈øpied by the Roman Centinels they a≈ø≈øi≈øted him, and brought him to the Senators, who received his Me≈ø≈øage, and immediately di≈øpatched him with an an≈øwer, ≈øo that he returned back to Camillus the ≈øame night; Next day one of the Gauls walking about that place, chanced to e≈øpy the prints and foot≈øteps of a man upon the Rocks and Gra≈øs which grew thereon; this he di≈øcovered to his Fellows, who thinking the Romans had now ≈øhew'd them the way, they took the opportunity of a dark night and a≈øcended the Hill the ≈øame way without being di≈øcovered either by the Men, or the Dogs who both kept guard there; but were now all fa≈øt a≈øleep; But it was the good fortune of the Romans that there were certain Gee≈øe, dedicated to Juno, and kept at the Publick Charge near her Temple, they being fearful by nature, and ea≈øily affrighted by the lea≈øt noi≈øe in the night, and being al≈øo kept very hungry by rea≈øon of the ≈øcarcity in the Capitol, may be ≈øuppo≈øed to have ≈ølept the more lightly, ≈øo that perceiving the Enemies with their glittering Armour, they flew again≈øt them, and filled the whole place with a fearful and unu≈øual cry, which awakened the Romans who ≈øu≈øpecting the matter‚ñ™ ran pre≈øently to the wall, and beat back their Enemies, throwing them down headlong, by which unu≈øual means the Capitol was ≈øaved, all the Gauls being forced to ha≈øten off, or to leave their dead bodies at the foot of the Hill they had newly climbed; In remembrance whereof, for a great while after, upon one day in the year they carried about in Proce≈ø≈øion a Dog hanged on a Gallows, and a Goo≈øe ≈øitting in a little chair of ≈øtate upon a rich and ≈øumptuous Cu≈øhion. Camerareus Medit.

12. Suctonius thus de≈øcribes that hou≈øe of Nero, which Nero him≈øelf called Domum Auream; The Golden Hou≈øe; In the Porch was ≈øet a Colo≈ø≈øus, or Image ≈øhaped like him≈øelf, of one hundred and Twenty foot high; The ≈øpaciou≈øne≈øs of the Hou≈øe was ≈øuch, that it had in
it three Galleries each of them a mile long, a ≈øtanding Pool like a Sea, be≈øet with buildings in manner of a City; Feilds in which were arable grounds, Pa≈øtures, Vineyards and Woods, with a various multitude of tame and wild Bea≈øts of all kinds; In the other part thereof all things were covered with gold, and di≈øtingui≈øhed with precious ≈øtones, as Mother of Pearl, &c. The Supping Rooms were roofed with Ivory planks that were moveable, for the ca≈øting down of Flowers; and had Pipes in them for the ≈øprinkling of Ointments; The Roof of the Principal Supping Room was round, which like the Heavens wheeled about perpetually day and night; This Hou≈øe when he had thus fini≈øhed and dedicated, he ≈øo mightily approved of that he ≈øaid, He then began to live like a Man. Suetonius Hi≈øt. Lib. 6.

XIII. The Amphitheatre begun by Ve≈øpa≈øian, but fini≈øhed and dedicated by Titus was mo≈øt famous, the height whereof was ≈øuch, that (≈øaith Marcellinus) the Eye of man could hardly reach it; It was built and reared up (≈øaith Ca≈ø≈øiodore) with Rivers of Trea≈øure poured out; It contained only upon the Steps and Degrees ≈øufficient and ea≈øie Seats for four≈øcore and ≈øeven Thou≈øand Per≈øons, ≈øo as the vacant Places be≈øides, might well contain Ten or Twenty Thou≈øand more; And it is admirable to con≈øider (≈øaith the L. Montaign in his E≈ø≈øays) what mighty magnificence the Roman Emperors u≈øed in their Theaters, It was wonderful (≈øaith he) to cau≈øe a great quantity of large Trees all full of green branches to be brought from far, and planted in Plots yeilding nothing but dry gravel, repre≈øenting a wild ≈øhady Forre≈øt, divided in due and ≈øeemly proportion; And the fir≈øt day to put into the Theatre a Thou≈øand E≈øtriges, a Thou≈øand Stags, a Thou≈øand Wild Boars, and a Thou≈øand Bucks, which were hunted and baited by the common people; The next day in the pre≈øence of all the People, an hundred great Lyons, an hundred Leopards, and three hundred huge Bears were baited and torn to peices; The third day three hundred couple of Gladiators or

In an In≈øtant all was dry and ≈ømooth again, and the Fencers entred and fought with each other; La≈øtly to compleat the la≈øt Act of one day only, the whole floor was forthwith clean≈øed, and ≈øtrowed over with Vermilion and Storax in≈øtead of Gravel, and a ≈øolemn banquet brought forth enough to entertain that almo≈øt infinite number of People; XIV. The Bridge of Caligula was a new and unheard of Spectacle, it reached from Puteoli to Bauli; three miles and a quarter, he built it upon Ships in a few days; Over this he marched with the Senate and Souldiery in a Triumphant manner, and in the view of the People; Upon this he fea≈øted, and pa≈ø≈øed the night in dalliance and Gaming; A Marvellous and great work indeed, but ≈øuch as the vanity thereof deprived it of Commendation, for to what end was it rai≈øed but to be demoli≈øhed? XV. Wales anciently extended it ≈øelf Ea≈øtward to the River Severn, till by the valour of Offa the great King of the Mercians, the Welch or Brittains were driven out of the plain Countrey beyond that River, and forced to betake them≈øelves to the Mountains, where he cau≈øed them to be ≈øhut up, and divided from England with an huge Ditch called Offa's Dike, which began where the River Wie comes into the Severn not far from Chep≈øtow, and extended four≈øcore and four miles in length, even as far as Che≈øter, where the River Dee is mingled with the Sea; which was a very ≈øtupendious work; Concerning this Ditch, there was a Law made by K. XVI. China is bounden on the North with Altay and the Ea≈øtern Tartars, from which it is ≈øeparated by

XVII. Ptolomeus Philopater built a Ship (≈øaith Pancirollus) that the like was never ≈øeen before nor ≈øince; It was two hundred and eighty Cubits in length, fifty two Cubits in height from the bottom to the upper Decks; It had four hundred Banks, or Seats for Rowers, four hundred Marriners, and four thou≈øand Rovers; And on the Decks it could contain Three Thou≈øand Souldiers, There were al≈øo Gardens and Orchards on the top of it, as Plutarch relates in the life of Demetrius.

XVIII. The E≈øcurial or Mona≈øtery of St. Lawrence in New Ca≈øtile in Spain was built by K. Philip 2. A place of ≈øuch Magnificence that no building in times pa≈øt, or the pre≈øent is comparable to it; The Front toward the VVe≈øt is adorned with three ≈øtately Gates, the middlemo≈øt whereof leadeth into a mo≈øt magnificent Temple, or Mona≈øtery, wherein were one hundred Monks of the Order of St. Jerom, and a Colledge; the Gate on the right hand openeth into divers Offices belonging to the Mona≈øtery that on the left hand to the Schools and outhou≈øes belonging to the Colledge; At the four Corners are four Turrets of excellent Workman≈øhip, and for height Maje≈øtical; Towards the North is the Kings Pallace, on the South part are divers beautiful and Sumptuous Gallerys, and on the Ea≈øt ≈øide ≈øeveral Gardens and Walks very plea≈øant and delectable; It containeth in all eleven ≈øeveral Quadrangles, every one incloi≈øtered, and is indeed ≈øo brave a Structure, that a Voyage to Spain were well imployed, were it only to ≈øee it and return.
